title: How to Preserve Dill

steps.headline: Collect dill just before the flower heads open for the most flavor.
steps.description: The dill leaves have their highest concentration of oils at this moment. Keep an eye on your dill and harvest it when you see the flower buds just starting to open up.Tip: Dill weed typically flowers between 2-3 months after it is planted. You can harvest dill anytime after the leaves are developed if you don’t want to wait for the flowers. However, dill loses some of its potency when you preserve it, so it’s ideal to harvest it when it has the strongest flavor for preservation.

steps.headline: Cut dill leaves off as close to the stem as possible using pruning shears.
steps.description: Carefully snip the dill leaves you want to harvest off of the main stem, right where the leaves meet the stem. Place them into a clean basket or container of some kind. Always use a sharp pair of pruning shears to harvest dill. If you don’t have shears, you can use a sharp pair of scissors instead. If you just pull the dill leaves off or damage them with a dull cutting tool, they become more prone to discoloration and decay.

steps.headline: Cut off any flower heads from the leaves.
steps.description: Use sharp pruning shears or scissors to snip off any flower heads that are attached to the leaves you harvested. This will leave you with just the flavorful dill leaves to preserve.

steps.headline: Rinse the dill leaves off thoroughly in a strainer.
steps.description: Place your harvested dill leaves in any kind of strainer. Rinse them under cool water from a tap and move them around with your hands to ensure that you clean them all. You can rinse the whole dill plant off with your hose or a watering can the day before you harvest them as an alternative to rinsing the leaves after. That way, you don’t have to worry about drying them too.

steps.headline: Pat the dill leaves dry with paper towels or clean kitchen cloths.
steps.description: Spread the leaves out on a clean cloth or a few paper towels. Use another clean cloth or paper towel to pat them down firmly until they are completely dry. Make sure that the dill is totally dry before you proceed to preserve it. Any lingering moisture can cause it to decay. You could also use a lettuce spinner to dry the dill leaves.

steps.headline: Place fresh dill leaves in a freezer bag and squeeze out the air.
steps.description: Put all the dill leaves you want to preserve into a sealable freezer bag. Squeeze out as much of the air as possible, then seal the bag’s zip top. Make sure there is no moisture on the dill leaves before you freeze them. If there is, pat them dry with paper towels or a clean cloth.

steps.headline: Put the bag of dill leaves into the freezer and store them for 4-6 months.
steps.description: Dill leaves will keep their best quality for up to 6 months in the freezer. They are still safe to use after that, but keep an eye out for signs of spoilage.Tip: The temperature of your freezer affects how long your dill can last. If your freezer is below 31 °F (−1 °C), it can get freezer burn and go bad more quickly. If you notice the dill becomes dark, discolored, or soft in the freezer, toss it out.

steps.headline: Take out only as much dill as you plan to use at a time.
steps.description: Take the bag out of the freezer, open it up, and take out however many dill leaves you want for a recipe. Squeeze all the air out of the bag, seal it up again, and put it back in the freezer right away. The more contact the dill has with air, the faster it can go bad, so try to limit its exposure as much as possible. Since dill leaves have very little volume, you don't have to wait for the dill to thaw out. You can just throw it right into any recipe you want to use it in.

steps.headline: Hang-dry dill to preserve the most flavor.
steps.description: Loosely bundle small bunches of dill leaves together by the stems with kitchen string or rubber bands. Hang the bundles upside down in a warm, dark, dry place where there is good air circulation for 1-2 weeks or until the leaves are dry and crisp enough that you can crumble them with your hands. If you don’t have a warm, dark, dry place to hang the dill, use a different method of drying. If it is too cold, damp, or bright, the dill leaves will just go bad.

steps.headline: Use a dehydrator to dry out dill, if you have one.
steps.description: Lay the dill leaves out in a single layer on a dehydrator tray. Set the dehydrator to 95 °F (35 °C) and dehydrate the dill for 4-6 hours or until the dill is dry enough that it crumbles in your fingers. Keep any eye on the dill after the first 4 hours to avoid overdrying it.

steps.headline: Dry dill in an oven when other methods aren’t an option.
steps.description: Set your oven to the lowest possible temperature. Spread the dill leaves out in a single layer on a cookie sheet and put them in the oven until they dry out and you can crumble them between your fingertips.Tip: The ideal temperature for drying out dill in an oven is below 95 °F (35 °C). If your oven’s temperature doesn’t go anywhere near this low, it’s probably not a good idea to dry out dill in your oven because you will just overdry it and kill the flavor. The amount of time this takes depends on how low your oven temperature goes, which is why it’s not an ideal method. Check on the dill every 5 minutes after the first 40 minutes to be safe.

steps.headline: Store dried dill in a sealable glass jar.
steps.description: Use your fingertips to crumble your dried dill leaves into a clean glass jar with a lid. Remove any large stems and screw the lid on tightly. Keep the dried dill this way indefinitely. You can use a mason jar or any type of small recycled jar with a screw-on lid.

text: Harvesting and Washing Dill Collect dill just before the flower heads open for the most flavor. The dill leaves have their highest concentration of oils at this moment. Keep an eye on your dill and harvest it when you see the flower buds just starting to open up.Tip: Dill weed typically flowers between 2-3 months after it is planted. You can harvest dill anytime after the leaves are developed if you don’t want to wait for the flowers. However, dill loses some of its potency when you preserve it, so it’s ideal to harvest it when it has the strongest flavor for preservation. Cut dill leaves off as close to the stem as possible using pruning shears. Carefully snip the dill leaves you want to harvest off of the main stem, right where the leaves meet the stem. Place them into a clean basket or container of some kind. Always use a sharp pair of pruning shears to harvest dill. If you don’t have shears, you can use a sharp pair of scissors instead. If you just pull the dill leaves off or damage them with a dull cutting tool, they become more prone to discoloration and decay. Cut off any flower heads from the leaves. Use sharp pruning shears or scissors to snip off any flower heads that are attached to the leaves you harvested. This will leave you with just the flavorful dill leaves to preserve. Rinse the dill leaves off thoroughly in a strainer. Place your harvested dill leaves in any kind of strainer. Rinse them under cool water from a tap and move them around with your hands to ensure that you clean them all. You can rinse the whole dill plant off with your hose or a watering can the day before you harvest them as an alternative to rinsing the leaves after. That way, you don’t have to worry about drying them too. Pat the dill leaves dry with paper towels or clean kitchen cloths. Spread the leaves out on a clean cloth or a few paper towels. Use another clean cloth or paper towel to pat them down firmly until they are completely dry. Make sure that the dill is totally dry before you proceed to preserve it. Any lingering moisture can cause it to decay. You could also use a lettuce spinner to dry the dill leaves. Freezing Dill Place fresh dill leaves in a freezer bag and squeeze out the air. Put all the dill leaves you want to preserve into a sealable freezer bag. Squeeze out as much of the air as possible, then seal the bag’s zip top. Make sure there is no moisture on the dill leaves before you freeze them. If there is, pat them dry with paper towels or a clean cloth. Put the bag of dill leaves into the freezer and store them for 4-6 months. Dill leaves will keep their best quality for up to 6 months in the freezer. They are still safe to use after that, but keep an eye out for signs of spoilage.Tip: The temperature of your freezer affects how long your dill can last. If your freezer is below 31 °F (−1 °C), it can get freezer burn and go bad more quickly. If you notice the dill becomes dark, discolored, or soft in the freezer, toss it out. Take out only as much dill as you plan to use at a time. Take the bag out of the freezer, open it up, and take out however many dill leaves you want for a recipe. Squeeze all the air out of the bag, seal it up again, and put it back in the freezer right away. The more contact the dill has with air, the faster it can go bad, so try to limit its exposure as much as possible. Since dill leaves have very little volume, you don't have to wait for the dill to thaw out. You can just throw it right into any recipe you want to use it in. Drying Dill Hang-dry dill to preserve the most flavor. Loosely bundle small bunches of dill leaves together by the stems with kitchen string or rubber bands. Hang the bundles upside down in a warm, dark, dry place where there is good air circulation for 1-2 weeks or until the leaves are dry and crisp enough that you can crumble them with your hands. If you don’t have a warm, dark, dry place to hang the dill, use a different method of drying. If it is too cold, damp, or bright, the dill leaves will just go bad. Use a dehydrator to dry out dill, if you have one. Lay the dill leaves out in a single layer on a dehydrator tray. Set the dehydrator to 95 °F (35 °C) and dehydrate the dill for 4-6 hours or until the dill is dry enough that it crumbles in your fingers. Keep any eye on the dill after the first 4 hours to avoid overdrying it. Dry dill in an oven when other methods aren’t an option. Set your oven to the lowest possible temperature. Spread the dill leaves out in a single layer on a cookie sheet and put them in the oven until they dry out and you can crumble them between your fingertips.Tip: The ideal temperature for drying out dill in an oven is below 95 °F (35 °C). If your oven’s temperature doesn’t go anywhere near this low, it’s probably not a good idea to dry out dill in your oven because you will just overdry it and kill the flavor. The amount of time this takes depends on how low your oven temperature goes, which is why it’s not an ideal method. Check on the dill every 5 minutes after the first 40 minutes to be safe. Store dried dill in a sealable glass jar. Use your fingertips to crumble your dried dill leaves into a clean glass jar with a lid. Remove any large stems and screw the lid on tightly. Keep the dried dill this way indefinitely. You can use a mason jar or any type of small recycled jar with a screw-on lid.

The dill leaves have their highest concentration of oils at this moment.
Keep an eye on your dill and harvest it when you see the flower buds just starting to open up.Tip: Dill weed typically flowers between 2-3 months after it is planted.
You can harvest dill anytime after the leaves are developed if you don’t want to wait for the flowers.
However, dill loses some of its potency when you preserve it, so it’s ideal to harvest it when it has the strongest flavor for preservation.
Cut dill leaves off as close to the stem as possible using pruning shears.
Carefully snip the dill leaves you want to harvest off of the main stem, right where the leaves meet the stem.
Place them into a clean basket or container of some kind.
Always use a sharp pair of pruning shears to harvest dill.
If you don’t have shears, you can use a sharp pair of scissors instead.
If you just pull the dill leaves off or damage them with a dull cutting tool, they become more prone to discoloration and decay.
Cut off any flower heads from the leaves.
Use sharp pruning shears or scissors to snip off any flower heads that are attached to the leaves you harvested.
This will leave you with just the flavorful dill leaves to preserve.
Rinse the dill leaves off thoroughly in a strainer.
Place your harvested dill leaves in any kind of strainer.
Rinse them under cool water from a tap and move them around with your hands to ensure that you clean them all.
You can rinse the whole dill plant off with your hose or a watering can the day before you harvest them as an alternative to rinsing the leaves after.
That way, you don’t have to worry about drying them too.
Pat the dill leaves dry with paper towels or clean kitchen cloths.
Spread the leaves out on a clean cloth or a few paper towels.
Use another clean cloth or paper towel to pat them down firmly until they are completely dry.
Make sure that the dill is totally dry before you proceed to preserve it.
Any lingering moisture can cause it to decay.
You could also use a lettuce spinner to dry the dill leaves.
Freezing Dill Place fresh dill leaves in a freezer bag and squeeze out the air.
Put all the dill leaves you want to preserve into a sealable freezer bag.
Squeeze out as much of the air as possible, then seal the bag’s zip top.
Make sure there is no moisture on the dill leaves before you freeze them.
If there is, pat them dry with paper towels or a clean cloth.
Put the bag of dill leaves into the freezer and store them for 4-6 months.
Dill leaves will keep their best quality for up to 6 months in the freezer.
They are still safe to use after that, but keep an eye out for signs of spoilage.Tip: The temperature of your freezer affects how long your dill can last.
If your freezer is below 31 °F (−1 °C), it can get freezer burn and go bad more quickly.
If you notice the dill becomes dark, discolored, or soft in the freezer, toss it out.
Take out only as much dill as you plan to use at a time.
Take the bag out of the freezer, open it up, and take out however many dill leaves you want for a recipe.
Squeeze all the air out of the bag, seal it up again, and put it back in the freezer right away.
The more contact the dill has with air, the faster it can go bad, so try to limit its exposure as much as possible.
Since dill leaves have very little volume, you don't have to wait for the dill to thaw out.
You can just throw it right into any recipe you want to use it in.
Drying Dill Hang-dry dill to preserve the most flavor.
Loosely bundle small bunches of dill leaves together by the stems with kitchen string or rubber bands.
Hang the bundles upside down in a warm, dark, dry place where there is good air circulation for 1-2 weeks or until the leaves are dry and crisp enough that you can crumble them with your hands.
If you don’t have a warm, dark, dry place to hang the dill, use a different method of drying.
If it is too cold, damp, or bright, the dill leaves will just go bad.
Use a dehydrator to dry out dill, if you have one.
Lay the dill leaves out in a single layer on a dehydrator tray.
Set the dehydrator to 95 °F (35 °C) and dehydrate the dill for 4-6 hours or until the dill is dry enough that it crumbles in your fingers.
Keep any eye on the dill after the first 4 hours to avoid overdrying it.
Dry dill in an oven when other methods aren’t an option.
Set your oven to the lowest possible temperature.

Spread the dill leaves out in a single layer on a cookie sheet and put them in the oven until they dry out and you can crumble them between your fingertips.Tip: The ideal temperature for drying out dill in an oven is below 95 °F (35 °C).
If your oven’s temperature doesn’t go anywhere near this low, it’s probably not a good idea to dry out dill in your oven because you will just overdry it and kill the flavor.
The amount of time this takes depends on how low your oven temperature goes, which is why it’s not an ideal method.
Check on the dill every 5 minutes after the first 40 minutes to be safe.
Store dried dill in a sealable glass jar.
Use your fingertips to crumble your dried dill leaves into a clean glass jar with a lid.
Remove any large stems and screw the lid on tightly.
Keep the dried dill this way indefinitely.
You can use a mason jar or any type of small recycled jar with a screw-on lid.
